carry.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to hold something in your hand or arms, or support it as you take it somewhere
carry.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Gina was carrying a small bunch of flowers.
Angela carried the child in her arms.
Let me carry that for you.
Jack carried his grandson up the stairs.
The waiter carried our drinks to the table.
carry.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to take people or things from one place to another in a vehicle, ship, or plane
carry.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: There are more airplanes carrying more people than ever before.
carry.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if a pipe, wire etc carries something such as liquid or electricity, the liquid, electricity etc flows or travels along it
carry.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: A drain carries surplus water to the river.
The aim is for one wire to carry both television and telephone calls.
carry.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to cause something to move along or support something as it moves along
carry.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: This stretch of water carries a lot of shipping.
The bridge carries the main road over the railway.
Pollution was carried inland by the wind.
carry.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to have something with you in your pocket, on your belt, in your bag etc everywhere you go
carry.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: I don’t carry a handbag. I just carry money in my pocket.
He says he’s got to carry a knife to protect himself.
carry.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to have something as a particular quality
carry.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: Few medical procedures carry no risk of any kind.
Older managers carry more authority in a crisis.
The plan is not likely to carry much weight with  (=have much influence over) the authorities.
If the child believes in what she is saying, she will carry conviction (=make others believe what she says is true).
carry.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: if a newspaper, a television or radio broadcast, or a website carries a piece of news, an advertisement etc, it prints it or broadcasts it
carry.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: The morning paper carried a story about demonstrations in New York and Washington D.C.
The national TV network carries religious programmes.
carry.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: if something carries information, the information is written on it
carry.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: All tobacco products must carry a health warning.
goods carrying the label ‘Made in the USA’
carry.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: to be responsible for doing something
carry.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: Each team member is expected to carry a fair share of the workload.
Which minister carries responsibility for the police?
Parents carry the burden of ensuring that children go to school.
carry.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: if a shop carries goods, it has a supply of them for sale
carry.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: The sports shop carries a full range of equipment.
carry.translation[0].definitions[10].def: if a wall etc carries something, it supports the weight of that thing
carry.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: These two columns carry the whole roof.
carry.translation[0].definitions[11].def: to take something or someone to a new place, point, or position
carry.translation[0].definitions[11].exa: The president wanted to carry the war to the northern states.
Blair carried his party to victory in 1997.
Clinton carried his campaign into Republican areas.
carry.translation[0].definitions[12].def: if a person, animal, or insect carries a disease, they can pass it to other people or animals even if they are not ill themselves
carry.translation[0].definitions[12].exa: The disease is carried by a black fly which lives in the rivers.
Birds and monkeys can carry disease.
carry.translation[0].definitions[13].def: if a crime carries a particular punishment, that is the usual punishment for the crime
carry.translation[0].definitions[13].exa: Drink-driving should carry an automatic prison sentence.
Murder still carries the death penalty.
carry.translation[0].definitions[14].def: if a sound carries, it goes a long way
carry.translation[0].definitions[14].exa: In the winter air, sounds carry clearly.
The songs of the whales carry through the water over long distances.
carry.translation[0].definitions[15].def: if a ball carries a particular distance when it is thrown, hit, or kicked, it travels that distance
carry.translation[0].definitions[16].def: to sing a tune using the correct notes
carry.translation[0].definitions[16].exa: I sang solos when I was six because I could carry a tune.
The highest voice carries the melody.
carry.translation[0].definitions[17].def: to persuade a group of people to support you
carry.translation[0].definitions[17].exa: He had to carry a large majority of his colleagues to get the leadership.
Her appeal to common sense was what finally carried the day (=persuaded people to support her).
carry.translation[0].definitions[18].def: if someone carries a state or local area in a US election, they win in that state or area
carry.translation[0].definitions[18].exa: Cuban Americans play an important role in whether he carries Florida in the fall campaign.
carry.translation[0].definitions[19].def: to stand and move in a particular way, or to hold part of your body in a particular way
carry.translation[0].definitions[19].exa: He had a way of carrying his head on one side.
She carried herself straight and with confidence.
carry.translation[0].definitions[20].def: if a group carries someone who is not doing enough work, they have to manage without the work that person should be doing
carry.translation[0].definitions[20].exa: The team can’t afford to carry any weak players.
carry.translation[0].definitions[21].def: if a woman is carrying a child, she is pregnant
carry.translation[0].definitions[22].def: to weigh a particular amount more than you should or than you did
carry.translation[0].definitions[22].exa: Joe carries only nine pounds more than when he was 20.
carry.translation[0].definitions[23].def: to put a number into the next row to the left when you are adding numbers together
carry.translation[0].note_box[0].section: carry out work
You’ll have to get a builder to carry out the work.
carry out your duties/responsibilities
She carried out her duties very efficiently.
carry out a task/job
He was unable to carry out simple tasks.
carry out research
I was in Italy carrying out research for my book.
carry out a survey
The committee has carried out a survey of parking problems in residential areas.
carry out a check
Manufacturers carry out safety checks on all new cars.
carry out a test
Forensic experts are now carrying out DNA tests.
carry out an experiment
Many schools need better facilities for carrying out scientific experiments.
carry out a review
The government is carrying out a review of state pension provision.
carry out a study
He has carried out various studies into violent behaviour.
carry out an investigation
The police will carry out an investigation into what actually happened.
carry out an inquiry
A formal inquiry into the cause of death will be carried out.
carry out an assessment
The company is carrying out an assessment of staff training needs.
carry out a search
Here are some more ways of carrying out information searches online.
carry out an attack
It became clear that terrorists had carried out the attack.
carry.translation[0].note_box[1].section: carry
to have something or someone in your hands or arms when you go somewhere
She was carrying a heavy suitcase.
Mary fainted, and had to be carried inside.
tote
to carry something such as a bag or a gun
He came out of the office toting a black leather briefcase.
Guards toting machine guns stood inside the airport.
lug
to carry something heavy, with difficulty
They lugged the mail in heavy canvas bags into the building.
cart
to carry something large and heavy somewhere, especially when this is annoying or hard work
We carted all the furniture upstairs.
schlep
to carry something heavy
Marty schlepped the suitcases upstairs.
bear
to carry something – used when talking about what someone has with them when they go somewhere. Bear is commonly used as a participle bearing
They arrived bearing gifts.
Anna returned, bearing a large red packet.
carry.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: the distance a ball or bullet travels after it has been thrown, hit, or fired
carry.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to move goods or passengers from one place to another
carry.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Airlines carried 262 million passengers on international flights last year.
carry.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: if a person or a company carries a debt, they have that amount of debt
carry.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The company still carries a lot of debt.
carry.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: Short-term loans carry higher interest rates.
The shares carry an annual dividend of $3.64 a share.
The issue carries triple-A ratings from both Moody’s and S&P.
carry.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: if a shop carries goods, it has them available for sale
carry.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: All of their stores carry the same merchandise.
